title: Can I learn computer science without going to school? What would be the necessary steps? - Quora
tags: Entry Level Career Advice in Computer Science
Career Advice and Computer Science Education

response.answer_text: The short answer to your question is Yes. My “title” is Software Engineer and I have no degree. I don't say this with pride, or to encourage others not to pursue education. I say this purely to show you what's possible. People often ask me how I got in my career. My faith is the number one reason, but this isn't a apiritual discussion so I will give you some serious action items. Be DecisiveYou need to eradicate all doubt of possibility from your mind. Decide it's possible and begin working. Which leads into… 2. Focus and Follow Through Once you've decided your going to learn CS shut everything else out and start working. Embarking on something new is thrilling, but what happens when you face challenges? Here is where “follow through”, “grit”, “tenacity” all come into play. Train yourself to enjoy the process of the “long game”. 3. Master Learning Itself Use this time to hone in your learning process. Learning CS is a lot like learning an instrument. Shorter consistent practice sessions everyday are going to benefit you more than binging 3 hours and forgetting most of what you learned. Also, constantly supplement theory with practical implementation. Don't just watch the tutorials, use the tutorials as inspiration for your own projects. Then use the tutorials as a supplement. BUILD THINGS CONSTANTLY. Some of the other answers have mentioned resources but I'll mention some here as well. Coding Problems: Codewars, Project Euler Education: MIT Open Courseware, Pluralsight, Udemy … That's the brunt of what you need. CS is very rewarding, and very much so an art in my opinion. Art executed through logic. If you take this on the skills you develop will be applicable everywhere. Stay consistent, and never back down.

If you have a masters in Chem you have the chops to learn CS. Just don’t be afraid of the material or the mystery. Each individual mystery, you’ll find, is incredibly small and pedestrian once you have understood it. Get the declarative nature of mathematics out of your head. Programming is not math, it’s procedural (e.g., “=” is the assignment operator, not a declaration of equality.)Understand that you are going to have to learn several disciplines simultaneously at first:Using the build tools, and the build processLearning the fundamentals of programming that apply to all languagesLearning the syntax and grammar of the language you chose to start withChoose a language that’s easy to learn. Start with Python. This is important because it eliminates all the hairy particulars of more stuffy languages and allows you to focus on the principles of programming. Learning additional languages is easy.Download the software for writing software.Start writing some programs. This will obviously involve seeking out some tutorials, or you can even find college lectures on YouTube. But writing programs is the only way to learn how to write programs. If you need exercise, visit About - Project EulerNever give up.

Absolutely! You could start by checking out MIT’s free courseware. The question becomes, what do you want to do with the knowledge? As you probably know, employers want education and/or experience. If you just want it for YOU, it doesn’t matter. If you want it so that you can say you are a computer engineer…then you need probably need the piece of paper.

People with good grasp of mathematics often happen to be stellar programmers. There’s a hell lot of free content on the web to learn from. Look up to MIT’s courses of NPTEL or anything similar. Just know that learning everything there is won’t be the right thing to do. Make sure you get the fundamentals right and try to specialize in something that you find interesting. Adios!
